introduction.p: In , perhaps you recognized the graph of the baseball's height as a parabola. In this chapter, we shall see that the graph of any quadratic function is a parabola.

note.p: In the definition above, notice that if a is zero, there is no x-squared term, so the function is not quadratic.

introduction.p: In , the height of a baseball t seconds after being hit was given by h = -16t^2 + 64t + 4 We used a graph to find two times when the baseball was 64 feet high. Can we solve the same problem algebraically?

We are looking for values of t that produce h = 64 in the height equation. So, if we substitute h = 64 into the height equation, we would like to solve the quadratic equation 64 = -16t^2 + 64t + 4 This equation cannot be solved by extraction of roots, because there are two terms containing the variable t, and they cannot be combined. To solve this equation, we will appeal to a property of our number system, called the zero-factor principle.

subsection.title: Zero-Factor Principle
subsection.p: Can you multiply two numbers together and obtain a product of zero? Only if one of the two numbers happens to be zero. This property of numbers is called the zero-factor principle.

The principle is true even if the numbers a and b are represented by algebraic expressions, such as x - 5 or 2x + 1. For example, if (x - 5)(2x + 1) = 0 then it must be true that either x - 5 = 0 or 2x + 1 = 0. Thus, we can use the zero-factor principle to solve equations.

ol.label: a
ol.li: Find the x-intercepts of the graph of f(x) = x^2 - 4x - 12.

li.p: We apply the zero-factor principle to the product (x - 6)(x + 2). \begin{aligned}[t] (x - 6)(x+ 2) \amp = 0 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Set each factor equal to zero.}}\\ x - 6 = 0~~ \amp\text{or} ~~ x+2=0 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Solve each equation.}}\\ ~~~x=6~~ \amp\text{or} ~~ x=-2 \end{aligned} There are two solutions, 6 and -2. (You should check that both of these values satisfy the original equation.)

To find the x-intercepts of the graph, we set y = 0 and solve the equation 0 = x^2 - 4x - 12 But this is the equation we solved in part (a), because (x - 6)(x + 2) = x^2 - 4x - 12. The solutions of that equation were 6 and -2, so the x-intercepts of the graph are 6 and -2. You can see this by graphing the equation on your calculator, as shown below.

subsection.title: Solving Quadratic Equations by Factoring
subsection.p: Before we apply the zero-factor principle to solve a quadratic equation, we must first write the equation so that one side of the equation is zero. Let us introduce some terminology.

ol.li: A quadratic equation written ax^2 + bx + c = 0 is in standard formstandard form.
A quadratic equation written a(x - r_1)(x - r_2) = 0 is in factored formfactored form.

subsection.p: Once we have written the equation in standard form, we factor the left side and set each variable factor equal to zero separately.

solution.p: First, we write the equation in standard form. \begin{aligned}[t] 3x(x + 1) \amp = 2x + 2\amp\amp \blert{\text{Apply the distributive law to the left side.}}\\ 3x^2 + 3x \amp = 2x + 2\amp\amp \blert{\text{Subtract }2x + 2 \text{ from both sides.}}\\ 3x^2 + x - 2 \amp = 0 \end{aligned} Next, we factor the left side to obtain (3x - 2)(x + 1) = 0 We then apply the zero-factor principle by setting each factor equal to zero. 3x - 2 =0 ~~\text{ or }~~ x + 1 = 0 Finally, we solve each equation to find x = \frac{2}{3} ~~\text{ or }~~ x = -1 The solutions are \dfrac{2}{3} and -1.

warning.p: When we apply the zero-factor principle, one side of the equation must be zero. For example, to solve the equation (x - 2)(x - 4) = 15 it is incorrect to set each factor equal to 15! (There are many ways that the product of two numbers can equal 15; it is not necessary that one of the numbers be 15.) We must first simplify the left side and write the equation in standard form. (The correct solutions are 7 and -1; make sure you can find these solutions.)

subsection.p: We summarize the factoring method for solving quadratic equations as follows.
We can use factoring to solve the equation from .

statement.p: The height, h, of a baseball t seconds after being hit is given by h = -16t^2 + 64t + 4 When will the baseball reach a height of 64 feet?

solution.p: We substitute 64 for h in the formula, and solve for t. \begin{aligned}[t] 64 = -16t^2 + 64t \amp + 4\amp\amp \blert{\text{Write the equation in standard form.}}\\ 16t^2 - 64t + 60 \amp= 0\amp\amp \blert{\text{Factor 4 from the left side.}}\\ 4(4t^2 - 16t + 15) \amp= 0\amp\amp \blert{\text{Factor the quadratic expression.}}\\ 4(2t - 3)(2t - 5) \amp= 0\amp\amp \blert{\text{Set each variable factor equal to zero.}}\\ 2t - 3 =0 ~~\text{ or }~~ 2t - 5 \amp= 0\amp\amp \blert{\text{Solve each equation.}}\\ t = \frac{3}{2} ~~\text{ or }~~ t \amp = \frac{5}{2} \end{aligned} There are two solutions to the quadratic equation. At t = \dfrac{3}{2} seconds, the ball reaches a height of 64 feet on the way up, and at t = \dfrac{5}{2} seconds, the ball is 64 feet high on its way down.

subsection.p: In the solution to , the factor 4 does not affect the solutions of the equation at all. You can understand why this is true by looking at some graphs. First, check that the two equations x^2 - 4x + 3 = 0 ~~\text{ and }~~ 4(x^2 - 4x + 3) = 0 have the same solutions, x = 1 and x = 3. Then use your graphing calculator to graph the equation Y_1 = X^2 - 4X + 3 in the window \begin{aligned}[t] \text{Xmin} \amp = -2 \amp\amp \text{Xmax} = 8\\ \text{Ymin} \amp = -5 \amp\amp \text{Ymax} = 10 \end{aligned} Notice that when y = 0, x = 3 or x = 1. These two points are the x-intercepts of the graph. In the same window, now graph Y_2 = 4(X^2 - 4X + 3) This graph has the same x-values when y = 0. The factor of 4 stretches the graph vertically but does not change the location of the x-intercepts.

subsection.p: The value of the constant factor a in the factored form of a quadratic function, f(x) = a(x - r_1)(x - r_2), does not affect the location of the x-intercepts, because it does not affect the solutions of the equation a(x - r_1)(x - r_2) = 0.

subsection.title: Applications
subsection.p: Here is another example of how quadratic equations arise in applications.

sidebyside.p: The size of a rectangular computer monitor screen is given by the length of its diagonal, as shown at left. If the length of the screen should be 3 inches greater than its width, what are the dimensions of a 15-inch monitor?

solution.p: We express the two dimensions of the screen in terms of a single variable:

We can use the Pythagorean theorem to write an equation. w^2 + (w + 3)^2 = 15^2 Solve the equation. Begin by simplifying the left side. \begin{aligned}[t] w^2 + w^2 + 6w + 9 \amp = 225\amp\amp \blert{\text{Write the equation in standard form.}}\\ 2w^2 + 6w - 216 \amp= 0\amp\amp \blert{\text{Factor 2 from the left side.}}\\ 2(w^2 + 3w - 108) \amp = 0\amp\amp \blert{\text{Factor the quadratic expression.}}\\ 2(w - 9)(w + 12) \amp= 0\amp\amp \blert{\text{Set each variable factor equal to zero.}}\\ w - 9 =0~~ \text{ or }~~ w + 12 \amp= 0\amp\amp \blert{\text{Solve each equation.}}\\ w =9{} ~~~\text{ or } ~~~{}w \amp= -12 \end{aligned} Because the width of the screen cannot be a negative number, we discard the solution w = -12. Thus, the width is w = 9 inches, and the length is w + 3 = 12 inches.

To include all the species of herbs, the planted area must be 300 square feet. Find the dimensions of the herb garden.

subsection.title: Solutions of Quadratic Equations
subsection.p: We have seen that the solutions of the quadratic equation a(x - r_1)(x - r_2) = 0 are r_1 and r_2. Thus, if we know the two solutions of a quadratic equation, we can work backward and reconstruct the equation, starting from its factored form. We can then write the equation in standard form by multiplying together the factors.

statement.p: Find a quadratic equation whose solutions are \dfrac{1}{2} and -3.

solution.p: The quadratic equation is \begin{aligned}[t] \left(x-\frac{1}{2}\right)\left[x-(-3)\right] \amp= 0\\ \left(x-\frac{1}{2}\right)(x + 3) \amp = 0 \end{aligned} To write the equation in standard form, we multiply the factors together. x^2 + \frac{5}{2}x - \frac{3}{2}= 0 We can also find an equation with integer coefficients if we clear the equation of fractions. Multiply both sides by 2: \begin{aligned}[t] 2\left(x^2 + \frac{5}{2}x - \frac{3}{2}\right)\amp= 2(0)\\ 2x^2 + 5x - 3 \amp = 0 \end{aligned} You can check that the solutions of this last equation are in fact \dfrac{1}{2} and -3. Multiplying both sides of an equation by a constant factor does not change its solutions.

statement.p: Find a quadratic equation with integer coefficients whose solutions are \dfrac{2}{3} and -5.

note.p: A quadratic equation in one variable always has two solutions. However, in some cases, the solutions may be equal. For example, the equation x^2 - 2x + 1 = 0 can be solved by factoring as follows: \begin{aligned}[t] (x - 1)(x - 1) \amp = 0\amp\amp \blert{\text{Apply the zero-factor principle.}}\\ x - 1 =0 ~~\text{ or } ~~ x - 1 \amp= 0 \end{aligned} Both of these equations have solution 1. We say that 1 is a solution of multiplicitymultiplicity two, meaning that it occurs twice as a solution of the quadratic equation.

subsection.title: Equations Quadratic in Form
subsection.p: The equation x^6 - 4x^3 - 5 = 0 is not quadratic, but if we make the substitution u = x^3, the equation becomes u^2 - 4u - 5 = 0 An equation is called quadratic in formquadratic in form if we can use a substitution to write it as au^2 + bu + c = 0 where u stands for an algebraic expression. Such equations can be solved by the same techniques we use to solve quadratic equations.

statement.p: Use the substitution u = x^3 to solve the equation x^6 - 4x^3 - 5 = 0

solution.p: We set u = x^3, so that u^2 = \left(x^3\right)^2 = x^6. The original equation then becomes a quadratic equation in the variable u, which we can solve by factoring. \begin{aligned}[t] u^2 - 4u - 5 \amp = 0 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Factor the left side.}}\\ (u + 1)(u - 5) \amp = 0 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Apply the zero-factor principle.}}\\ u + 1 \amp = 0~~ \text{ or }~~u - 5 = 0\amp\amp \blert{\text{Solve each equation for }u.}\\ u \amp = -1 ~~ \text{ or }~~ u = 5 \end{aligned} Finally, we replace u by x^3 and solve for x. \begin{aligned}[t] x^3 \amp = -1 ~~~~~~~\text{ or } \amp x^3 \amp= 5\amp\amp \blert{\text{Take cube roots.}}\\ x\amp= \sqrt[3]{-1} = -1 ~~~\text{ or } \amp x \amp = \sqrt[3]{5} \end{aligned} You can verify that the solutions of the original equation are -1 and \sqrt[3]{5}.

subsection.p: We say that the equation in , x^6 - 4x^3 - 5 = 0, is quadratic inquadratic in x^3. We chose the substitution u = x^3 because x^6 = u^2.

statement.p: Use the substitution u = x^2 to solve the equation x^4 - 5x^2 + 6 = 0.

subsection.p: Usually, you can choose the simpler variable term in the equation for the u-substitution. For example, in we chose u = x^2 because u^2 = \left(x^2\right)^2 = x^4, which is the first term of the equation. Once you have chosen the u-substitution, you should check that the other variable term is then a multiple of u^2; otherwise, the equation is not quadratic in form.

solution.p: We use the substitution u = e^x, because u^2 = \left(e^x\right)^2 = e^{2x}. The original equation then becomes \begin{aligned}[t] u^2 - 7u + 12 \amp = 0 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Factor the left side.}}\\ (u - 3)(u - 4) \amp = 0 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Apply the zero-factor principle.}}\\ u - 3 \amp = 0 ~~\text{ or } ~~ u - 4 = 0 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Solve each equation for} u.}\\ u \amp =3 ~~\text{ or } ~~ u = 4 \end{aligned} Finally, we replace u by e^x and solve for x. \begin{aligned}[t] e^x \amp =3 ~~~~~\text{ or }\amp e^x \amp= 4\\ x \amp = \ln (3) ~~~\text{ or }\amp x \amp= \ln (4) \end{aligned} You should verify that the solutions of the original equation are \ln (3) and \ln (4).
